data.title: Autosave overrides currently open file
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Enable autosave with 10sec delay
2. Open a file and change something
3. Switch to another file without saving
4. On auto save the open / active file gets overriden by the file which is currently saving.

data.title: Intellisense and Error Detection Not working in 1.6.0
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.0
- OS Version: Mac OS Sierra 10.12
- Plugins: ms-vscode.csharp 1.4.1, EditorConfig.EditorConfig 0.3.3

After upgrading from 1.5.3, Intellisense and Error Detection seem to have stopped working.  I am coding a .NET Core project written in C#.

What happens is that Intellisense and Error Detection show up (i.e. the red squiggly underlines) when I make an edit in my C# file.  However, after a moment, they disappear again and I can't get them to stay visible.

I noticed that JS/Node/Typescript users seem to be having a similar issue, So I will mention that we do have one JS file in this project as well as a `package.json`.  The purpose of this one JS file is to do a cross-platform script that will build the whole project in one go.  Regardless, this issue happens no matter if the JS File is opened or closed in VS Code.

data.title: reveal-option when opening a document
data.body:
When you call `showTextDocument` you _can_ pass in which column a `TextDocument` should be opened. It works perfectly if it being opened for the first time, but if that `TextDocument` was already opened before, on a different column, you may end up with two views of the same `TextDocument`. 

I didn't find any API to check if the `TextDocument` is/was already opened, or any API to access the `Stacks/Columns`, so I could search for that `TextDocument` and detect the correct column to be used. I only found `onDidChangeTextEditorViewColumn` event, that appears to be a way to _follow_ the changes.

Thanks for your help.

data.title: Suggestion: Quickfix should respect arrow keys if given scrollbar
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6
- OS Version: OS X El Capitan (10.11.6)

![](http://i.imgur.com/YBjoBL6.gif)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open quick fix (`alt + .` / `cmd + .`) 
2. Use Arrow keys
3. Observe you are able to move up and down but the scroll bar doesn't move when you move past the top or bottom suggestion

Note: You are able to scroll with the mouse wheel

I honestly don't remember if this was the case pre-1.6. I thought that it showed all available suggestions in the window and didn't need to scroll.

data.title: Suggestion: improve the presentation of the API documentation
data.body:
I have a hunch you guys already know this is important, but I can't see any other issues to this effect.

Is it just me, or is the [API documentation](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/extensionAPI/vscode-api) user experience pretty awful right now? I posted this issue just now in response to trying to find out what the API has to offer with respect to some ideas I have. Key questions in mind are "is it directly capable of X" and "can I get a sense of how much additional work would be required to extend certain base features to support my ideas?"

Problems:
- It's a giant scrolling page; clumping everything together makes it hard to differentiate between different sections and judge how they relate to each other.
- There is nowhere to get a quick overview of everything the API has to offer.
- There is no obvious table of contents that I can use to quickly jump to the section I need.
- There is no clear document hierarchy.
- I can't quickly search for symbols and drill down to find what I need (other than via CTRL+F)
- It's not very readable. The typography makes everything look kind of "same-ish", so it's hard to scroll through and scan for what I need. The font sizes don't make a lot of sense with respect to representing importance of items and their relationship to the document hierarchy.
- Weird line spacing- way more space between property list items than headings and so forth. Again, scannability is an issue.

Would love to see this presented in a way that encourages better absorption and exploration of what the API has to offer, and I'm sure doing so would promote a faster-growing extension ecosystem.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/298883/19334565/13ad6778-9140-11e6-8c84-58009ad59729.png)

As an aside; "Complex Commands API" - The intro text is completely unhelpful: _"They are called complex commands because they require parameters and often return a value"_ - this is a description of almost every function in existence.

data.title: How auto run Javascript on devtools at startup?
data.body:
Hi @bpasero @dilijev :sweat_smile: and VS Code community!
- VSCode Version: 1.6.0
- OS Version: Manjaro KDE Ellada 16.08

Steps to Reproduce: _(hide activity bar)_
1. Open devtools console
2. Copy and paste this line `document.getElementById("workbench.parts.activitybar").remove();`
3. Execute and then the node is removed
4. `ctrl + b` for autofix layout

I do this almost every time when I use VS Code, Can I automate it?

The trick source is [here](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/1105#issuecomment-214830681) 

This is related to #1105 and others.
Also I know that the idea is _on going_, but How can I do it :point_up_2: while I wait for this new awesome feature?

I tried to edit the vscode internal files as `workspace.main.js` and `index.js` without successful results.
Also I tried via extension, but [VS Code don't allow it](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/extensions/our-approach)

Bye  :raising_hand_man:

data.title: Updating two configs through API in sequence may break settings file
Can not activate joaomoreno.git while debugging extensions if settings.json file is open
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.0-Insiders
- OS Version: macOS

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open Hello World extension
2. Press F5 to debug
3. A new instance shows up, do not open any folder, just open user settings.
4. Restart the debugging process
5. The new instance restarts and shows `Activating extension "joaomoreno.git" failed: Cannot read property 'length' of undefined.`

data.title: instanceof and is lose type when reassigning.
'cat' is not recognized as an internal or external command when running code.cmd
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.0
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. VS Code is installed but not added to PATH
2. Run `[vscode-install-dir]\bin\code.cmd ./a-file.txt`
3. It shows an error that cat is unknown

code.cmd pipes to cat, but cat is not on the PATH. It should be fully qualified like so:
`call "%~dp0..\Code.exe" "%~dp0..\resources\\app\\out\\cli.js" %* | "%~dp0\cat"`

The bug was introduced [here](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/commit/6fa85223efb25ad7ce3e534c7eb07edd9524bd6d#diff-e62d56b48816ae21d577db74d3386bb8R1)

data.title: Improve Windows support in integrated terminal
data.body:
Currently pty.js drives communication to and from the terminal's shell process but there are some issues with the way it's setup:
- To get it building with the newer node.js and to integrate with our Windows code signing I was forced to fork it to [Tyriar/pty.js](https://github.com/Tyriar/pty.js).
- The fork is a fork ([Tyriar/pty.js](https://github.com/Tyriar/pty.js)) of a fork ([platformio/pty.js](https://github.com/platformio/pty.js)) of a fork ([jeremyramin/pty.js](https://github.com/jeremyramin/pty.js)) of the original ([chjj/pty.js](https://github.com/chjj/pty.js))  and it probably doesn't have to be.
- The original is not really maintained anymore.
- ~~The current commit being used is on a branch called prebuilt but the prebuilt assets were removed to get signing working on [Tyriar/pty.js](https://github.com/Tyriar/pty.js).~~ The prebuilt branch was copied over the master branch https://github.com/Tyriar/pty.js/tree/master
- All versions of pty.js depends on a fork ([peters/winpty](https://github.com/peters/winpty)) of a very old version of [rprichard/winpty](https://github.com/rprichard/winpty) which includes quite a few changes, including changes to the API. I believe this old version of winpty is the root cause for several [windows-specific terminal issues](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues?q=is%3Aopen+is%3Aissue+label%3Aintegrated-terminal+label%3Abug+label%3Awindows).
- We should publish to Tyriar/pty.js to npm, particularly since it [now has more consumers](https://github.com/zeit/hyper/pull/946) than just vscode https://github.com/Tyriar/pty.js/issues/9

data.title: Incorrect syntax highlighting in method when its return type ends with a digit
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.0
- OS Version: Windows 7 Ultimate 64-bit

![52b3a02d1b41db8613640eebd5acfc47](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17408083/19323694/4bbc74e2-90be-11e6-8d01-b450afc2e573.png)
![11084e2699fc5974741ae34d11117827](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17408083/19323699/4ea4a0ee-90be-11e6-8ae2-f63238dca1fe.png)

It seems to be caused by the return type ending in a digit (or multiple digits). Having a digit in the return type before the last character does not cause it. Same issue appears when the return type ends with the $ character.

data.title: onDidCloseTextDocument for preview pane has significant delay
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.0
- OS Version: Mac 10.11.6

The onDidCloseTextDocument event seems to not fire for minutes after the closing of a preview pane, where as it works perfectly for normal text documents. Last time I tried, I timed it at taking 2 minutes and 30 seconds to fire after closing a preview pane. In my application I am dependent on this to clean up data that was being held for the preview pane.

Is this a bug? or is there a different way to detect when a preview pane specifically is closed to clean up data (a handler specific for content providers maybe)?

Repro located at https://github.com/anthonydresser/vscodeRedirectTest

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a document and use the `Test Redirect` command to open a preview pane
2. Put a breakpoint on the ondidclose handler in the testProvider
3. Close the preview pane

data.title: Extension update available to older versions of VSCode
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.3
- OS Version: Windows 10 x64

A user has reported that an extension update for [vscode-jumpy](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=wmaurer.vscode-jumpy) is available: wmaurer/vscode-jumpy#3
However the newest update requires engine ^1.6.0.

Clicking the update button doesn't apply the newest extension version (correct, as expected).

The bug is, that the newest update requiring ^1.6.0 should not be available to users of 1.5.3. Or at least a warning should be displayed saying the newest version of the extension is only compatible with newer versions of VSCode.

data.title: Unsecure node included, needs update
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.6.0 (e52fb0bc87e6f5c8f144e172639891d8d8c9aa55, 2016-10-10T18:37:40.189Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.10586
- Extensions: 

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Goto Help menu, choose About, notice Node 6.5.0
2. Goto https://nodejs.org/en/ and notice a big "Important security notes for recent OpenSSL and Node.js vulnerabilities" and click on it
3. Take notice of all vulnerabilities
4. Change the dependencies for this package to Node 6.7.0 or newer from active LTS branch
5. Launch a new version with not vulnerable Node included

data.title: Module identifiers with jsx extension won't work anymore
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.0
- OS Version: Windows 10.1 x64

With the previous version of VS Code it was possible to inspect module imports from jsx files by using this:

`import reducer from './reducer/index';`
`import App from './components/App';`

So an import without an extension. This is no problem for webpack...

But now in VS Code 1.6 with the new Typescript version the inspection doesn't work anymore. Maybe because of this: [https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/wiki/What%27s-new-in-TypeScript#including-built-in-type-declarations-with---lib](url)

So using
`import reducer from './reducer/index.jsx';`
`import App from './components/App.jsx';`
also doesn't work.

The only thing that work is the js extension, but for jsx this is not a good solution

`import reducer from './reducer/index.js';`
`import App from './components/App.js';`
